title: 104_hr3222
content: The Act titled "Hippocratic Oath and Patient Protection Act of 1996" outlines the duties of a health carrier. The "Hippocratic Oath and Patient Protection Act of 1996" mandates that a health carrier must not restrict a healthcare provider's communication with patients or the public, operate improper incentive plans, or include certain indemnification clauses. Additionally, the health carrier must disclose all services and benefits offered under the health plan in plain language to both healthcare providers and enrollees. The "Hippocratic Oath and Patient Protection Act of 1996" prohibits health carriers from limiting or denying services or benefits under the health plan, and from implementing improper incentive plans for healthcare providers. SEC. 3. PROTECTED COMMUNICATION. A protected communication is relevant information for patient care. Limitations include trade secrets and intentional misrepresentations by healthcare providers. SEC. 4. IMPROPER HEALTH CARE PROVIDER INCENTIVE PLAN. SEC. 4 outlines that a health care provider incentive plan must meet specific requirements to be considered proper. It defines such a plan as any arrangement that could limit services for an enrollee. SEC. 5 prohibits indemnification clauses that protect health carriers from liability in civil actions brought by enrollees or healthcare providers. SEC. 6 addresses enforcement. SEC. 6 of the Act allows the Secretary of Health and Human Services to impose civil money penalties on health carriers for violations, ranging from $25,000 to $100,000 per violation. Procedures for penalties are outlined in subsections of the Social Security Act. SEC. 7 grants individuals the right to seek relief through civil action for violations of the Act. SEC. 8 requires a report to Congress. SEC. 8 of the Act mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to submit a report to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The report will evaluate the impact of the Act on health carriers, healthcare providers, and enrollees, as well as the enforcement of the Act. Recommendations for necessary changes to ensure compliance by health carriers will also be included in the report. The term "health plan" in this Act refers to any entity or program that provides payments for healthcare, including group health plans, health insurance arrangements, and workers' compensation related insurance. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to health insurance, including "health care provider," "health carrier," and "enrollee." These terms are crucial for understanding the regulations surrounding healthcare services and insurance coverage. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATES. Subsections 2(1) (A) and (C) take effect upon enactment of the Act and apply to contracts entered into before or after that date. Subsections 2(1)(B) and 2(2) take effect 90 days after the Act's enactment and apply to contracts entered into before or after that date.
